definition: to judge the hour and size up the situation/to take stock
to pass/to spend (time)/measure/limit/extent/degree of intensity/degree (angles, temperature etc)/kilowatt-hour/classifier for events and occurrences

sentences.english: No, you will not see them when sizing up the shoreline.
sentences.chinese: 不，你不會看到他們時，審時度勢海岸線。

sentences.english: It was time to take stock of the situation.
Until then, we will remain cautious and assess the situation as it unfolds.
sentences.chinese: 不過，在這之前，我們會保持謹慎，審時度勢。

definition: to show one's colors/to have a clear-cut stand (idiom)
to follow through/to carry through to the end
bring order out of chaos/set to rights things which have been thrown into disorder
highest common factor HCF/greatest common divisor GCD
to obscure the facts (idiom); to mislead the public with prevarication and deliberate falsehoods
to charge and break through enemy lines
magnificent army with thousands of men and horses (idiom); impressive display of manpower/all the King's horses and all the King's men
unprecedented and never to be duplicated/the first and the last/unmatched/unique
rigorous schemes and deep foresight (idiom); astute and circumspect
